Award.AwardTitle: Pan-American Advanced Studies Institute on Cells to Ecosystems: Frontiers in Collaborative Quantitative Physics-Based Multiscale Modeling of Complex Biological Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Pan-American Advanced Studies Institutes (PASI) award, jointly supported by the NSF and the Department of Energy (DOE), will take place in July, 2013 at the Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS) in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. Organized by Dr. James A. Glazier of the Physics Department at Indiana University in Bloomington, the institute will focus on many of the key mathematical approaches currently used in modeling biological phenomena in contemporary biology. The development and function of tissues and organs rely on a complex web of interactions that occur on a multitude of scales ranging from individual proteins to tissue networks. The PASI will gather leading researchers from a variety of modeling disciplines to teach their methodologies through lectures and computer laboratories, and to promote interdisciplinary collaborations among participants in order to address key biological problems. PASI participants will include experimental biologists, computational biologists, and mathematical biologists at the advanced undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate levels.

This PASI will introduce students to many important techniques in the above subjects. In addition to the exposure and mentoring of young scientists to state-of-the-art methods, the activity will foster international collaboration among researchers from the US and different countries in the Americas. The results from the PASI, including presentations and videos, will be disseminated through a website and other media to serve as a resource for students and researchers interested in biological modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Pan-American Advanced Studies Institute was held in Porto Alegre, Brazil in July 2013. Its intellectual merit derived from its ability to gather a group of leading researchers in the field of multiscale modeling of complex biological processes together in one location to interact with students in a setting which promoted interpersonal interactions, collaboration, the exchange of ideas, and in depth discussions. Its broader impacts derived from its systematic approach to participant selection to ensure that the chosen participants  represented a) a cross-section of countries throughout the Americas, b) a diversity of educational backgrounds including both theorists and experimentalists from diverse fields (such as mathematics, physics, physiology, plant biology, genomics, and developmental biology) who wished to study biological processes at different biological scales such as cells, tissues, organisms, and ecosystems,  and c) a mix of career stages ranging from undergraduates to graduates and post- doctoral fellows.  The 12 instructors represented 10 institutions from 4 countries including the US, Brazil, Uruguay, and the UK. The 27 students represented 5 nations including the US, Mexico, Brazil, Colombia, and Canada. Instruction was provided in a mixed format of 30 classroom lectures, 10 symposium lectures, and 30 hands-on computer lab tutorials. Each of the students was given the opportunity to present an in-class presentation about their research focus. Ample time was provided within the structure of each day for informal discussions outside of formal class time.  It is anticipated that as a result that participants may develop models to address biological processes which have not been modeled previously and that existing models of biological processes will be improved and refined.
